intro: Scaphula, commonly known as the "buttercup" or "yellow water lily," is a genus of aquatic plants belonging to the family Nymphaeaceae. It is characterized by its floating leaves that are typically round or heart-shaped with a waxy surface. The flowers are showy, with bright yellow petals and a central cluster of stamens. Scaphula thrives in still or slow-moving freshwater environments. Its botanical features make it an important component of wetland ecosystems.
